list.content: Yesterday I finally came around to achieving the capability of deploying the same piece of code on all devices: mobile, desktop, and web. This makes me happy as it tells me that I have reached a milestone I have set a few years back.

content: I remember as a kid running towards a rainbow in order to stand under it. I ran quite the distance, and I only stopped when my path was completely blocked by some private property.
Thinking about that day, I always thought that if I ran far enough, I would have been able to stand under that rainbow, because the arch felt so close that day.
It was only years later in school that I learned if I see a big rainbow facing me, I am probably under it even if it appears ahead.
The most time I spend on these daily posts actually goes to choosing a color palette and design. I try to find some interesting new way of applying colors on the card.
Some days I finish the card with the feelings of amusement for the result, and some days I just get bored and decide that whatever I chose is just fine.

It's so easy to destroy things that take decades to build

content: Social media let us know how "stupid" other people's thoughts are. Then we had the great idea of weaponizing those thoughts.
Some say that some portion of online malignancy ceased with the sanctions against Russia. I'm not sure what to think about that.

list.content: I'm scared for the world...
I'm healthy, safe and comfortable; and I'm grateful for these.

content: After flying around for a while she was off her hype state. She was able to see that these metal chunks didn't stop for anything, they also growled like those dangerous big birds, but only worse.

She realized that these things weren't as innocuous as our little bird predicted. They seemed to be dangerous. Still she loved how they looked from afar. She realized that her mom knew something that maybe she didn't know yet.
This was a let down, she was heartbroken but also proud of herself for being open enough to observe these things instead of mindlessly diving in.
list.notes: This was inspired by a conversation about a bedtime story with Bossonica

list.content: She is still flying and she is so so happy to finally be near her beloved cars. I think we should let her enjoy her moment.
list.notes: This was inspired by a conversation about a bedtime story with Bossonica

content: Soon enough, she was flying over territory that was easily the farthest she has ever been from her mother's nest. It was exciting!

As she got closer to the giant rolling pieces of metal, she realized that she could see through some parts of these things. She quickly realized that there were these giant creatures inside. They looked like the creatures that came near to her nest. Some of them gave her and her sisters food, some were scary and mean.

Our bird was puzzled. She didn't know what this new discovery meant about the majestic metals. Was it safe to be near these things? They now seemed to be in alliance with the giant creatures at the park. Her mom always said that you cannot trust these creatures. That they may be good but also very very bad.
The little bird was worried but she wanted to try her luck. She was still going to be safe. "I won't land on anything this time, just fly around and look at my giant metals from distance"
list.notes: This was inspired by a conversation about a bedtime story with Bossonica

content: Once upon a time there was a little bird living in a park in a big big city. She had a very sheltering mom that din't want her to wander off too far. She would tell the little bird 'There is so much you don't understand about the city, it's not safe'. Our little bird hated to hear this, she thought her mom was super duper omg omg dramatic.

Our little bird had a huge passion. She would see these huge metal things passing by, so fast, so majestic. She wanted to be near these things. She once heard one of the other birds call them 'cars'. She wasn't sure though. All she knew was that she desperately wanted to know more about these things.
One day while her mom was out, finding food for our little bird and her sisters, she decided to get out of the park and take a look at these majestic chunks of metal. She was so excited...
list.notes: This was inspired by a conversation about a bedtime story with Bossonica

list.content: I missed studying math
Restraint is a virtue only when there is an alternative.
Since my last link, I have been dealing with software things that I thought would have taken a day tops. I was so so wrong.
Paper was such an expensive commodity: something hard to find; something that spoke of royalty, power and intellectualism. Now we literally wipe our asses with it.
It's amazing how much our early lives influence our path in life.

So many empires came and went. They all knew about others that came before. They probably knew that their efforts would crumble like their predecessors. They invented noble reasons for their ultimately futile efforts; called them glory, remembrance, duty

list.content: Have a great trip Bossonica!
I read about people's trust in their leaders and their government during the earlier decades, and it feels almost unbelievable.
When I watch these end-of-the-year recaps, I always feel surprised by how much has happened. Remember hearing all of those events but they flee from my consciousness quite fast.

list.content: Considering the entire history of the planet, these so called ancient civilizations like Sumers, Akads and Elamites were really not that ancient.
You can find joy in all sorts of things if you have a "joy" plug installed in your head.
I wonder whether a period like dark ages would ever emerge at the global scale.
New land is being created and destroyed in Tonga right now.
We are gathered here today to celebrate the life of my coffee maker, which is one of the two that died within the last two months. Now you can make coffee for Einstein and Segovia among the clouds.

list.content: I sometimes imagine myself traveling to the past to tell people about what today's world is like. I try to imagine how they would perceive what the world has become.
How much bad should be allowed for the greater good?

list.content: Why do land animals have bladders? I can't really tell what kind of an evolutionary advantage being able to hold your bladder offers.
Gummy bears are my favorite candy

We have poetry, theater, books, movies, all kinds of art, and all genres of music; we developed AR and VR, built all kinds of immersive games and experiences on top of them. But despite all of these amazing ways of communication, we cannot even start to understand how someone else sees the world unless we have been in their shoes.
So much changes in so little time while it feels like nothing changes overall.
People don't like Matrix sequels, but I disagree. They have some amazing moments and they do an amazing job of turning the trope of "hero's journey" on its head.
Not everything needs serious thought.
So many expect someone else to love them before they love themselves.
If you have to choose between bird-man and man-bird, always choose bird-man.
Pencils used to be a regular part of my life. Now it's incredibly rare that I use one for anything other than signing my name.
Turns out, not everyone wants to be able to fly...
I wholeheartedly want James Webb Space Telescope to successfully deploy and show us all the amazing things we cannot yet see
